trial_identification.studytitle: An observational study that evaluates the improvements in auditory performance (hearing) and health related benefits (quality of life) achieved by children using implantable hearing devices: Cochlear Paediatric Implanted Recipient Observational Study (Cochlear P-IROS)
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A global prospective observational study (patient registry) to assess the effectiveness of implantable hearing devices in children implanted at < 10 years of age, in their everyday life.

interventions.interventions: The use of cochlear implants, bone conduction implants, other implantable hearing devices in the treatment of hearing loss , over a period of 2 years (minumum)- 5 years (maximum) post implantation.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Intra-subject comparison of post-implantation auditory skills (CAP_II)
primaryOutcome.timepoint:
Each subject will be evaluated at 0, Months, 6 months, 12 months, 18 months and 24months post implantation
Those continuing in the study, after two years, will be assessed on annual basis. That is at 3 years, 4 years and 5 years post implantation.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Inter-subgroup comparison of auditory skills (CAP-II and SSQ for Parents)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint:
The evaluation timepoints are baseline (0 months), 6 months, 12months, 18 months and 24 months post implantation.
Those continuing in the study, after two years, will be assessed on annual basis. That is at 3 years, 4 years and 5 years post implantation

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Children < 10 years of age at time of first implantation; Received an regulatory approved implantable hearing device/s;
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Prior experience with an implantable hearing device Implantable devices not yet approved for sale by regulatory authority

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: No 1 University Avenue Macquarie University, NSW 2109

fundingsource.fundingaddress: No 1 University Avenue Macquarie University, NSW 2109

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To address these reported gaps in the literature regarding the clinical efficacy of implantable hearing devices, a global prospective observational study (a patient registry) has been developed to assess the effectiveness of hearing habitation with the aid of implantable hearing devices in infants and young children up to the age of 10 years, in their everyday life.
ethicsAndSummary.publicnotes:
Observational studies do not require EC approval in all jurisdictions.
The first centre to join the trial and recruit patients did not require EC. This means that he first patients recruited occured before the first EC approval was granted, which is appropriate in this context.
No patients will be recruited before EC approval is granted in a jurisdiction in which EC approval is applicable.
